BE

Trump’s intent to completely repeal Obamacare (PPACA Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act) has several important implications, some of which were outlined in our report A Citi/ Capital Alpha Conference Call - Pharma’s Achilles Heels. The View from the Hill. These include (i) removal of IPAB pricing control mechanism (ii) removal of 351k biosimilars approval pathway (iii) reduced coverage of low income individuals previously covered under Medicaid eligibility, as well as individuals who have now since enrolled under the ACA (iv) removal of measures to fill the Medicare part D donut hole (v) disbanding ACOs. The net impact of all the above measures, if repeal takes place, is near-term positive for the industry outlook. However, we anticipate that in the event of a successful repeal of PPACA, the GOP will introduce alternative market driven reforms to stem pharmaceutical cost inflation. Trump has previously proposed direct Medicare price negotiation, re-importation of overseas drugs and increased price transparency in order to control rising pharmaceutical costs. Near-term we continue to expect the sector to rally. We note the GOP’s lack of a senate supermajority is a barrier to repeal in 2017, but repeal may still be possible through budget reconciliation or in future years depending on the size of the GOP’s Senate majority. We highlight longer term implications in today’s earlier report Trump Victory - Healthcare Investors Celebrate While You Can. M&A Ahead. We prefer BUY rated GSK, AZN, Shire and Roche among the EU majors. We prefer BUY rated BMY and LLY in the US.

New legislation likely will protect the biosimilar pathway in event of an ACA repeal.
The 351K biosimilar pathway was approved as part of the PPACA. Novartis’s Zarxio, Pfizer/Celltrion’s Remsima and Amgen’s Amjevita have been approved under this pathway to date with many more pending submissions. We anticipate any Republican administration will likely seek to introduce new legislation to preserve the 351k pathway. Near-term beneficiaries of biosimilar uncertainty include Roche, Abbvie (both BUY rated) among the pharmaceutical companies.

BE

Repeal of IPAB removes low probability negative.
IPAB-enforced price controls always looked a remote possibility even if triggered, in the absence of a Democrat clean sweep. The potential repeal of PPACA is nonetheless a helpful positive for industry sentiment.

PM

Donald Trump Wins the 2016 Presidential Election, With Republicans Controlling Both House and Senate
Based on 87% of votes counted at 7:39 GMT and most states reporting, with Michigan, Wisconsin and Arizona yet to declare, Donald Trump has won with 276 electoral votes (EVs), compared to 218 EVs for Clinton. Republicans have retained their majority in the House of Representatives and Senate. This result delivers Trump and the Republican Party a rare political mandate. Trump has no experience in government, and his tenure as President will likely be marked with unconventional, and potentially erratic, policymaking that departs substantially from the political modus operandi of the past, whether Republican or Democrat. This expectation of change was a major driver of his popular appeal, but it is likely to unsettle markets.

11:17 am
PM

What Happens Next?
The new president will take office on Inauguration Day – 20 January 2017.1 Until then, President Obama and the current Congress will preside over what is known as the “Lame Duck” session. During this period we expect the omnibus bill to fund nondiscretionary federal spending to be passed, and to decide the fate of a few expiring tax provisions. The coming weeks will also feature announcements about nominees for key posts, such as Treasury Secretary and the Secretaries of Defense and State, all of whom must be confirmed by Congress in the new session.

PM

eightened US Political Risk Continues
Trump will start his Presidency with low favorability ratings and without experience of government and the negotiations with Congress that are required to see policies enacted. With a Republican sweep, President Trump would have greater scope to enact his campaign agenda of tax cuts and expansionary spending. But success is not guaranteed, given divisions even between Republicans. Fiscal hawks may balk at Trump’s deficit-enlarging proposals, while conservatives might oppose Trump’s more liberal policies such as paid family leave. President Trump likely would also find resistance from a majority Republican Congress if he pursues policies that limit international trade or sour US relations with its foreign allies, given they are in opposition to longstanding party orthodoxy.

PM

There should be an H at the beginning of that

11:18 am
PM

How Would Trump Govern? – This campaign featured limited articulation of policy proposals, and some of the ones Trump has described – such as building a wall on the Mexican border – are likely unenforceable. US presidents have the greatest impact on foreign and security policy, and trade. It is in these areas that Trump may diverge most sharply from the previous status quo.

PM

Foreign Policy – We expect a more isolationist foreign policy with the possibility for deterioration in relationships between US and allies, particularly if Trump acts on his threat to force US allies to pay more for their own security and to withdraw the US from NATO. Confrontation with China over trade policy is possible, but tensions with Russia could decline, particularly in the event that Trump reduces or eliminates the US role in NATO. Europe is particularly exposed to Trump risk, given its longstanding security relationship with the US. He has also vowed to reverse the Iran nuclear deal, potentially a major blow to diplomacy as well as reviving the risk of an attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities.

PM

On the Economy – Trump’s stated economic policies have centered on tax cuts for households and firms, expanded infrastructure spending, and unspecified offsets in other public spending. He advocates reduced regulation (especially for the financial and energy sectors), but more Congressional accountability and oversight of the Fed’s monetary policy decisions (likely with the imposition of a rules-based policy framework on the Fed, see here). Trump might further restrict immigration, and deport undocumented persons. His rhetoric also suggests he would aggressively try to renegotiate many existing trade agreements and challenge China on trade and currency policies, which could spark global recession-inducing trade wars.

11:18 am
PM

How Much Power Will Trump Wield? – Although the US political system has embedded checks and balances (see here), there are a number of tail risks associated with a Trump Presidency. These include international trade wars that might result in higher inflation, more uncertainty, reducing consumer spending and eroding business confidence vital for boosting business investment. Mass deportations, reduced Fed independence, runaway Federal budget deficits and unmanageable debt are also notable tail risks.
Fed – We currently expect the Fed to hike rates by 25 basis points in December. A Republican sweep of the White House and both chambers of Congress raises the risk that Trump will find support to pursue his more ambitious campaign agenda items such as invoking a trade war that may weaken US net exports and reduce business investment. This is our near-term recession risk scenario, that likely would either keep the Fed on hold indefinitely, or even prompt interest rate cuts to offset the recession-related damage to the US and global economies.

PM

Debt Ceiling Showdown – We do not expect Congress to resolve the debt ceiling problem ahead of the March 15, 2017 “soft” deadline. We anticipate little action on the debt ceiling until early summer at the earliest or early fall at the latest. When the “hard” debt ceiling hits, we anticipate that Congress will suspend the ceiling for another year or two as it is unlikely that the budgetary changes – greater revenue and or less spending – required for reigning in Federal deficits will have been legislated to curb public debt accumulation.

BE

Here's Citi again.

BE

Trump corporate tax credits could hurt renewables economics / more likely than PTC or ITC reversal

BE

Key exposure to the US (2018 revenues)
Vestas c40%, SMA Solar c45% , Nordex c10-15%, Gamesa via Siemens exposure (c20% of WP revenues) and Senvion 0%. Senvion is least exposed name with zero exposure however with potential to gain exposure to the US. Similarly Nordex does not currently have exposure to the US, however it is likely that Nordex will gain exposure into the US by 2018 with US order flow in 2016

11:29 am
BE

TC and ITC
These tax credits are key for the wind and solar markets in the US. They provide project owners an incentive of $23/MWh in form of tax credit to build onshore wind and solar PV farms. In late 2015 (see publication PTC/ITC extension late 2015) the extension of both credits were passed by Congress. With broad congressional support, it will be tough for Trump to repeal these legislations despite the fact that Republicans have won the House and Senate. A sizeable part of the onshore wind value chain is located in Republican-leaning states, which would likely make repealing the PTC/ITC a sensitive matter to Congress.

BE

RPS
We think it is also unlikely Trump will contest state-specific renewables portfolio standards – he would have to tackle each state individually and would interfere in state politics. Currently 29 states have these standards in place.

BE

Tax breaks for corporates
It is more likely that Trump’s proposed tax breaks would alter the economics of renewables projects. Trump has proposed cutting corporate taxes to a maximum of 15% (see Trump’s tax reform) from currently maximum 35%. This would have two negative effects on the economics of renewable energy projects: (1) lower demand for PPAs which are already at depressed levels and (2) render MACRS (accelerated depreciation) less advantageous for developers
Net
With the sell-off seen so far investors are pricing in a heightened probability of the worst case scenario – No PTC/ITC. In this extreme case onshore wind and solar PV installations would collapse to levels close to zero. However, there are many hurdles to jump through. It is more likely tax breaks would somewhat slow PPA demand and render renewables projects less economic.

BE

Here's Exane to explain.

BE

The likely Trump victory poses a threat to US-Mexican trade relations
With Mr. Trump’s infamous comments on North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) being the ‘worst trade deal ever’ (not to mention the wall on the Mexican border), his victory raises fears that the US-Mexico free trade agreement will be at risk.

11:39 am
BE

Mexico opening was a game changer for the US HFCS industry

Following a decade of frustration, the US HFCS industry finally gained unfettered access to Mexico in 2006 as a result of a bilateral agreement mandated by NAFTA. This served to create a multi-year bull run (which has effectively continued until today) in the US corn sweetener industry. Should NAFTA come under pressure, HFCS looks very likely to be one of the first industries to be impacted (the Mexican sugar lobby is very strong).

BE

Losing Mexican access would be disastrous for the HFCS industry

Capacity utilization effectively determines US HFCS industry profitability. As outlined in our report earlier this week (see HFCS profits to hit a wall?), we estimate that losing Mexican access would see industry capacity utilization plummet from 90% to 78%, a level not seen since 1997. Industry profits would very likely collapse (as a guestimate, -50% feels a reasonable).

BE

We expect Tate shares to de-rate as concerns on Mexico build

Given that North American corn sweeteners account for c.40% of Tate’s EBIT, we expect Trump’s victory to drive a material de-rating in Tate’s shares.

11:40 am
BE

We downgrade to Underperform. TP to GBP5.70

Given there is no visibility on the timing and scope of any potential changes in the US-Mexico trade relations, it is difficult to quantify the near-term impact on Tate’s financials. As a consequence, we leave our estimates unchanged. However, in recognition of the risk we now value Tate at its historical trough P/E multiple relative to peers (45% discount to Consumer Ingredients sector). Our target price moves from GBP7.60 to GBP5.70. We downgrade to Underperform.

PM

Our view: Passenger growth has been healthy but outstripped by increased capacity. Hence load factors dipped. Unit revenues also remain weak due to excess capacity in the market and the need to discount fares to fill cabins. Lower fuel costs helped to offset weaker yields. The outlook statement is cautious and we think that consensus forecasts will remain unchanged with this statement. The search for a new CEO is ongoing following the surprise resignation of Saad Hammad in late October. FLYB is trading at a significant premium to the sector (NTM PE +64%) and as usual the investment case hangs on whether the company can materially lift margins this winter and over the next year or so. Pending further updates with management we maintain our HOLD recommendation but our TP remains Under Review.

11:46 am
PM

1H update – FLYB has provided an earnings update for 1H. Adjusted profit before tax, at £15.9m, was about in line with our forecast for £16.3m (-2.5%). Flybe UK passenger numbers were up 7.1% to 4.8m but this was outstripped by capacity growth with seats up 13.5%. Hence the load factor was down 4.3pts to 72.0% (the budget carriers in Europe are averaging over 90% loads currently). Unit revenues were also weak with a 6.9% decrease in passenger revenue per seat to £50.80. Offsetting weaker unit revenues FLYB has benefited from lower fuel costs with total cost per seat down by 5.8%. Flybe UK launched 43 new routes during the period as well as 18 daily and 58 weekly frequency increases.

· CEO unexpectedly resigned in late October – FLYB announced on 26 October that CEO Saad Hammad had resigned with “immediate effect” and by “mutual agreement”. The stock has reacted sharply, falling by 13% since this announcement. The statement today has no new news (other than to confirm that a salary of £433.5k plus £30k compensation will be paid) and the search for a CEO is ongoing.

· Outlook is vague and cautious – FLYB is facing a similar challenging operating environment to most of its peers. Excess seat capacity in the European short-haul market combined with a weaker pound and softer business sentiment is impacting all carriers. The company reiterates that it has a robust balance sheet and cash position (i.e. £141.7m of total cash and with net debt at just £24.8m). Going forward, FLYB will benefit from lower fuel costs (i.e. 92% of the fuel requirement for H2 2016-17 is hedged at an average price of $533 per tonne). That said, given the weaker outlook on yields we do not expect changes to consensus forecasts today. FY17 consensus forecasts are currently: revenue of £679m, EBITDA £45m, EBIT £8.7m and EPS 2.1p (source: Factset).

· Valuation, risks and TP - On consensus forecasts, FLYB is valued on a NTM PE of 12.8x vs. the sector on 7.8x, or a 64% premium to the sector. Risks include demand for regional passenger airline services, competitor capacity and fuel costs. Our TP, which is currently Under Review, is determined using a 10-year DCF of net cash flows. Our preferred stock, on valuation and fundamental grounds, is easyJet (EZJ LN – BUY – TP 1,300p).

Effectively a second Brexit that leaves many very surprised, including
the markets and me.

It's going to take a significant amount of time to assess the
implications beyond the short term.

Increased levels of uncertainty will mean more hesitation to make
important decisions in the short term, both by people and governments.
But it may accelerate implementation of helpful reforms in the medium
term to reduce uncertainty and stimulate investment as a result.

Clearly immigration, trade and terrorism were key issues that swayed
electoral opinion in a very significant way, just as they did in the
UK, and probably will in the European referenda and elections to come.

There will now be a lot of reassessment, including of polling
techniques. Electorates at times like these clearly don't like to be
told how they're going to vote, especially by the media and other
elites.

12:01 pm
PM

Throughout the election, our forecast models have consistently come to two conclusions. First, that Hillary Clinton was more likely than not to become the next president. And second, that the range of possible Electoral College outcomes — including the chance of a Donald Trump victory, but also a Clinton landslide that could see her winning states such as Arizona — was comparatively wide.

That remains our outlook today in our final forecast of the year. Clinton is a 71 percent favorite to win the election according to our polls-only model and a 72 percent favorite according to our polls-plus model. (The models are essentially the same at this point, so they show about the same forecast.) This reflects a meaningful improvement for Clinton in the past 48 hours as the news cycle has taken a final half-twist in her favor. Her chances have increased from about 65 percent.
